newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: CRICKET-AUSTRALIAN LEG-SPINNERS DELIVER SERIES WIN.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-AUSTRALIAN LEG-SPINNERS DELIVER SERIES WIN.

text.p: Australia's new-found leg-spin Twins, Shane Warne and Michael Bevan, took 16 wickets between them to hand their side a series-deciding victory in the fourth test against West Indies at the Adelaide Oval on Tuesday.

Australia won by an innings and 183 runs on the fourth day of the test against a hapless West Indies side to take an unbeatable 3-1 lead in the best-of-five match series and retain the Frank Worrell trophy they won in the Caribbean in 1995.
Bevan, originally picked three years ago as a batsman, capped his transformation this season into a dangerous left-arm leg-spinner with 10 wickets in the match.
He took six for 82 in the West Indies' second innings, fooling the tourists' top order time and again with his pace and variety.
Bevan, who also scored an unusually circumspect 85 not out, was named man of the match.
Warne, Australia's established leg-spinning wizard, showed he was still amoung the best in the world by taking three for 68 in the second innings and six wickets for the match.

West Indies lost the match within the first hour of the fourth day, but their fate had been effectively sealed when they self-destructed to be all out for 130 in their first innings on the first day on what was generally regarded as a good batting wicket.
Australia proved how good the wicket was in their first innings, scoring 517 in under two days.
West Indies, led by a defiant Brian Lara with 78, performed a little better in their second innings but were still unable to resist the guiles of Bevan and Warne to be all out for 204.

Australia's victory came near the end of a topsy-turvy summer which saw them begin the series with two crushing wins in November and December before slumping to a run of losses in limited overs matches and a capitulation inside three days in the third test in Melbourne.
Australia then missed out on a place in the finals of their annual World Series tri-nation limited overs competition for the first time since the 1979/80 series.
Australia and West Indies now travel to Perth for the fifth test starting on Saturday.
